title: Best casserole dishes for heart-warming stews, chillis and soups
text:
As the colder nights begin to settle, it’s hardly surprising we start to crave wholesome, hearty one-pots such as soups, stews and casseroles.

But, in order to do the job properly, it’s important to invest in a good-quality casserole dish: a trusty kitchen companion if there ever was one.

Casserole dishes vary across the market, catering for all styles, tastes and budgets, so it can be tricky deciding exactly which model to opt for.

From cast iron to stoneware to aluminium, and round to shallow to oval, we tested an array of styles, shapes and sizes – and ate a lot of chilli in the process.

Primarily, we were looking for dishes which completed the task at hand efficiently; those with non-stick bases, or those which cooked food evenly and thoroughly fared favourably in our testing.

We were also looking for dishes with a large capacity, ideally being oven-safe as well as suitable for the hob.

Bonus points were given to those which could be transported from hob to oven to table, and could look the part, too.

Overall, a good casserole dish is worth investing in, and should last more than just one season. With this in mind, we were also keen to find dishes which were durable, hard-wearing and could promise longevity: something you would want to (and would be able to) cook with time and time again.

You can trust our independent reviews. We may earn commission from some of the retailers , but we never allow this to influence selections, which are formed from real-world testing and expert advice. This revenue helps to fund journalism across The Independent.

Sophie Conran for Portmeirion large white large casserole dish: £67.99, Portmeirion

This ceramic-coated non-stick cast aluminium casserole dish was everything we were looking for. On top of being functional – it can be used on all stove tops, including gas and induction, and oven safe up to 180C – its ribbed, ceramic coating makes it a stylish addition to any kitchen or table. We especially loved its clear lid, made of heat-resistant tempered glass, which enabled us to see how our food was cooking, and prevent any burning or overcooking. It holds an impressive 3.lL, but isn’t so heavy to be-off putting to use or clean. It’s also dishwasher-safe. As it’s made from aluminium, you’ll need to refrain from putting it in the microwave, and watch out for the handle and lid getting hot while cooking – have a pair of oven gloves at the ready.

Buy now

MasterClass cast aluminium 20cm casserole dish 2.5l: £34.99, Lakeland

This stylish pressure cast aluminium pan looks as though it could weigh a lot more than it does, and it’s suitable for picking up with one hand, even when full. It holds 2.5l and is both oven (up to 200C) and hob safe. Its speckled interior, on top of being pleasing to the eye, is reinforced with a non-stick and anti-scratch interior for evenly-cooked food. It heats quickly and evenly and its secure-fitting lid (which encourages steam to condense and ultimately to baste the food) makes it ideal for slow cooking. It’s an ideal family-sized oven-to-table dish, and doesn’t take up too much room either.

Buy now

Wilko 24cm aluminium shot blast casserole dish, £20: Wilko

If you’re running low on olive oil, this casserole dish has a handy shot-blasted coating, meaning you can cook with little – or no – oil or fat. It can be used on gas, electric and induction hobs, but you won’t be able to put this one in the oven, so best to stick to liquid-based dishes such as casseroles which don’t need grilling baking. It’s surprisingly lightweight given its size and depth, and its monochrome speckled coating makes it stylish enough to leave on display after cooking, should you so wish. It’s also dishwasher-safe – overall a great option for just £20.

Buy now

M&S cast aluminium casserole: £49.50, M&S

This beautiful-looking cast aluminium casserole dish comes in such a lovely shade of pistachio we’re now tempted to redecorate our kitchen. Also available in teal, ivory, charcoal and red, this would look impressive on any dinner table. It’s lightweight but also durable, and can be used on the hob, and in the oven (up to 200C). It has an impressive 5l capacity – ideal if you’re feeding a crowd – and handily, can be placed in the dishwasher afterwards.

Buy now

Le Creuset signature shallow casserole: £210, Le Creuset

There’s a reason why Le Creuset is one of the most coveted kitchen brands out there. As well as producing casserole dishes in a rainbow of colours, it’s a brand you can rely on, with dishes often becoming family heirlooms. Le Creuset’s cast iron casserole dishes (available in round, oval and shallow) are no exception. We found this one to be the best for our requirements, particularly given its versatility; on top of cooking risottos and casseroles, the dish is adept at browning meat thanks to its shallow depth. It’s compatible with the hob and the oven, and is definitely one for placing in the middle of a table; the cast iron handily keeps everything warm.

Buy now

Staub 20cm round cocotte in white truffle: £199, Borough Kitchen

These celebrated cast iron pans from France come in a range of sizes and colours to suit all kitchens, but it’s the 20cm La Cocotte that comes out top for us. Perfectly round with attractive embossing and a beautiful sheen, it certainly it looks the part – but it has more to offer than just good looks. While it’s heavy, the cast iron evenly distributes heat and helps to prevent food from burning. Its sturdy, snugly-fitting lid has been well-thought out, too; it’s designed to capture moisture which, as it condenses, drips back onto the food and enhances flavour and consistency. It’s wonderfully versatile and can be used on all types of hob, or can be placed in the oven and under the grill. It’s no wonder these dishes are loved by chefs such as Bibendum’s Claude Bosi.

Buy now

Pro Cook oval cast iron casserole, £69: Pro Cook

Offering similar styles, sizes and colours to more pricier counterparts, Procook’s range of casserole dishes are sturdy, robust and designed to last. We particularly enjoyed this one, which can hold an impressive 6.2l – just the thing if you’re looking to batch cook. It’s suitable for all hob types and the oven (up to 260C) and even comes with a 25 year guarantee. It can be placed in the dishwasher, but it’s recommended that it’s washed by hand – you wouldn’t want to compromise its striking colourways anyway.

Buy now

Denby 20cm halo round casserole dish: £100, Denby

This compact 20cm dish isn’t so large that it can’t be left on the side, and thanks to its classy enamel finish, you’ll want to have it out on display or placed in the middle of the table at dinner. That said, it can still serve up to at least four people, and has a capacity of 2.4l. Looking for a larger dish? This round design is also available in 24cm and 26cm sizes On top of casseroles, it’s also good for soups, sauces and rice dishes and is handily oven-safe up to temperatures of 250C. It comes with a lifetime guarantee, as well as a recipe book covering chilli, roast lamb and more.

Buy now

Argos Home 3l cast iron shallow casserole dish: £45, Argos

Given its size, quality, and the fact that it’s made from cast iron, this is a good-value casserole dish. It’s versatile, too, and can be used to whip up soups, stews, chillies, casseroles and curries. It can also be transferred from hob to oven (up to 240C) and to the table. We found it to be easy to clean, and particularly enjoyed the fact it looks like it should cost a lot more than it actually does.

Buy now

Morso casserole dish 1.7l: £109, Morso

Danish designers Morso may be celebrated for their outdoor cookware, but their minimalist kitchenware also impresses – and their 1.7L capacity casserole dish is one such example. While you cannot fault its elegant look, it’s also designed to be used, rather than to just sit there and look pretty. It’s suitable for all hobs, oven and grill types (that includes barbecues!), and is versatile enough to cater for everything from soups and casseroles to roast chicken and even bread.

Buy now

The verdict: Casserole dishes

The Sophie Conran casserole dish is a great mid-price all-rounder which conducts heat effectively and makes a stylish table centrepiece, while the M&S cast iron casserole dish is well-designed and affordable, and is available in some fantastic colours. At the upper end, Le Creuset’s signature shallow casserole is ideal for feeding a crowd or batch cooking and has the promise of longevity. For those looking for a budget-friendly option, Lakeland’s cast aluminum casserole dish is lightweight, compact and efficient.

IndyBest product reviews are unbiased, independent advice you can trust. On some occasions, we earn revenue if you click the links and buy the products, but we never allow this to bias our coverage. The reviews are compiled through a mix of expert opinion and real-world testing.
description: Now it's autumn invest in a casserole dish to make stews, chillis and soups from Argos, Lakeland, Le Creuset and Denby
